message_1:
Let X be the unit circle in the xy-plane, i.e. X = {(x,y) | x^2 + y^2 = 1}. Let f:X -> X be the function defined by f(x,y) = (-x,-y) for all (x,y) in X. 
Find the fundamental group of X with respect to the basepoint (1,0).
message_2:
The fundamental group of a topological space is a group that captures information about the "holes" in the space. In this case, we are considering the unit circle X in the xy-plane, which is a simple closed curve with no holes. The fundamental group of X with respect to the basepoint (1,0) can be found using the concept of homotopy classes of loops based at the point (1,0).

A loop in X based at (1,0) is a continuous function α: [0,1] -> X such that α(0) = α(1) = (1,0). Two loops α and β are homotopic if there exists a continuous function H: [0,1] x [0,1] -> X such that H(0,t) = α(t), H(1,t) = β(t), H(s,0) = H(s,1) = (1,0) for all s,t in [0,1]. The set of all homotopy classes of loops based at (1,0) forms a group under the operation of concatenation of loops, denoted as π₁(X, (1,0)).

In the case of the unit circle X, it is well-known that the fundamental group is isomorphic to the integers, i.e., π₁(X, (1,0)) ≅ ℤ. This is because any loop based at (1,0) can be continuously deformed into a loop that winds around the circle an integer number of times, either in the positive (counterclockwise) or negative (clockwise) direction. The integer represents the "winding number" of the loop, and the group operation corresponds to adding the winding numbers of two loops.

In summary, the fundamental group of the unit circle X with respect to the basepoint (1,0) is isomorphic to the integers, i.e., π₁(X, (1,0)) ≅ ℤ.
